question:
Mma Agatha:
It is important for people to take risks, both in professional lives and their personal lives. Do you think the advantages of taking risks outweigh the disadvantages?


Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
text: Risk-taking is seen to be of a significant both in  career and individual lives. While this appears to have some benefits,  it is equally associated with some setbacks. I feel that the merits surpasses the drawbacks as we shall see.

Admittedly,  there are few disadvantages of taking dangerous steps, perhaps the most notable one is failure. There are usually multiple failings before succeeding with an idea,  so people will rather chose to pitch at the safer side of life.  Furthermore,  this can be because,  it would requires lots of efforts and hardwork to sustain the initially made decision and  most people do not have such capability  required.

However,  this trend is associated with great advantages,  the greatest being the success outcomes it brings. Those who took daring decisions are often seen enjoying the after mount effects, of which most times, are positive.  This can be relatable with the  happenings and with some of the motivational speaaches given by public figures in the society.  In addition,  audacious steps are perceived to be a motivating force. Humans generally need some forms of encouragement, and see taking risky decisions as a way of challenging themselves to become better. Hence, they go to the extra mile in carrying out  tasks including dangerous ones. For example,  Serena Williams, the world table tennis Champion, had described how she was able to achieve success by doing a daily 20 hours of practice despite her health being at stake.

In conclusion,  it seems that people take risks both personally and professionally,  the fear of its outcome as well as the inability to  work hard, renders this debate negative.  The success stories and the motivating effects it comes with,  supersedes every setback this might present.
